full_text: Case 1:20-cr-00330-PAE Document 499-2 Filed 11/23/21 Page 106 of 159105 LBAAMAX3ps Rocchio - Cross psychologist is to not independently investigate what the client may or may not be telling you, correct? A. In a treatment setting for the patients that I'm treating, yes, that's correct. Q. You don't go out and talk to witnesses or try to prove or disprove whatever your client is telling you in the treatment setting, correct? A. Correct. Q. It wouldn't be appropriate for you to do that, correct? A. Correct. Q. And generally, you're accepting what the client is telling you as the presenting problem and then you are trying to treat that presenting problem during the course of your therapy, correct? A. Yes. Q. I want -- you talked a bit about your job as a forensic psychologist. How many times have you testified as a forensic psychologist? A. In a courtroom or also in depositions? Q. Both. Let's start with courtroom. I think you said twice. Correct? A. Yes. Q. And one of those was a criminal case where you testified on behalf of the defendant; is that right? A. Yes. SOUTHERN DISTRICT REPORTERS, P.C. (212) 805-0300
